December 4, 2011: Fiction
KILL ALEX CROSS, by James Patterson. (Little, Brown, $28.99.) Alex Cross
investigates when the president’s children are kidnapped, but the F.BI. and C.I.A.
stand in his way.
11/22/63, by Stephen King. (Scribner, $35.) An English teacher travels back to 1958 by
way of a time portal in a Maine diner. His assignment is to stop Lee Harvey Oswald.
V IS FOR VENGEANCE, by Sue Grafton. (Marian Wood/Putnam, $27.95.) Pursuing a
shoplifter, Kinsey Millhone discovers that retail crime is run by organized gangs.
THE LITIGATORS, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $28.95.) Partners in a small law firm
take on a big case after a fast-track burnout joins them.
DEVIL'S GATE, by Clive Cussler and Graham Brown. (Putnam, $27.95.) In the ninth
NUMA Files novel, Kurt Austin and his crew uncover a plan to blackmail major nations.
THE BEST OF ME, by Nicholas Sparks. (Grand Central, $25.99.) Twenty-five years
after their high school romance ended, a man and woman who have gone their
separate ways return to their North Carolina town for the funeral of a friend.
ZERO DAY, by David Baldacci. (Grand Central, $27.99.) A military investigator
uncovers a conspiracy.
STAR WARS: THE OLD REPUBLIC : REVAN, by Drew Karpyshyn. (LucasBooks,
$27.) A Jedi stumbles upon a terrible secret that threatens the Republic; a “Star Wars”
novel.
THE CHRISTMAS WEDDING, by James Patterson and Richard DiLallo. (Little, Brown,
$25.99.) A widow keeps the identity of the new man she is about to marry a secret.
1Q84, by Haruki Murakami. (Knopf, $30.5.) In 1980s Tokyo, a woman who punishes
perpetrators of domestic violence has ties to an aspiring novelist with an unusual
project.
THE SNOW ANGEL, by Glenn Beck. (Threshold Editions/Mercury Radio Arts, $21.) A
woman re-evaluates her life.
OUT OF OZ, by Gregory Maguire. (Morrow/HarperCollins, $26.99.) Elphaba’s
granddaughter Rain takes up her legacy; Book 4 (the final volume) of the Wicked
Years.
THE MARRIAGE PLOT, by Jeffrey Eugenides. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $28.) Three
Brown graduates in the early 1980s wrestle with love, religion and coming of age.
LOST DECEMBER, by Richard Paul Evans. (Simon & Schuster, $19.99.) A prodigal
son turns his life around during the holiday season.
December 4, 2011
Non-Fiction
STEVE JOBS, by Walter Isaacson. (Simon & Schuster, $35.) A biography of the
recently deceased entrepreneur, based on 40 interviews with Jobs conducted over
two years.
KILLING LINCOLN, by Bill O'Reilly and Martin Dugard. (Holt, $28.) The
commentator looks at the heart-stopping events surrounding the assassination of
Abraham Lincoln.
IMPERFECT JUSTICE, by Jeff Ashton with Lisa Pulitzer. (Morrow/HarperCollins,
$26.99.) A prosecutor’s account of the Casey Anthony trial.
JACK KENNEDY, by Chris Matthews. (Simon & Schuster, $27.5.) An admiring
portrait.
HOW I GOT THIS WAY, by Regis Philbin. (It Books/HarperCollins, $25.99.) The
recently retired co-host of “Live! With Regis and Kelly’’ looks back on his years in
show business.
GABBY, by Gabrielle Giffords and Mark Kelly with Jeffrey Zaslow. (Scribner,
$26.99.) The Arizona representative and her astronaut husband describe their lives
in the aftermath of the assassination attempt against her in January 2011.
UNBROKEN, by Laura Hillenbrand. (Random House, $27.) An Olympic runner's
story of survival as a prisoner of the Japanese in World War II.
BACK TO WORK, by Bill Clinton. (Knopf, $23.95.) The former president argues that
cooperation between the private sector and government is necessary to restore
prosperity.
THEN AGAIN, by Diane Keaton. (Random House, $26.) The actress uses her
mother’s diaries as a springboard for the examination of her own life.
NO HIGHER HONOR, by Condoleezza Rice. (Crown, $35.) A memoir of service
during the Bush administration.
THE NEW NEW RULES, by Bill Maher. (Blue Rider, $26.95.) Humorous
observations on politics and life.
BOOMERANG, by Michael Lewis. (Norton, $25.95.) A look at some of the places —
Greece, Ireland, Iceland — hardest hit by the financial collapse of 2008, and at how
it happened.
THROW THEM ALL OUT, by Peter Schweizer. (Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, $26.)
Insider trading in Congress and how it enriches the permanent political class.
THINKING, FAST AND SLOW, by Daniel Kahneman. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $30.)
The winner of the Nobel in economic science discusses how we make choices in
